---
Working from home, frustrated with separate hardware environments, staring into a small laptop screen or dragging cables around a bulky docking station? There's an elegant solution to that. Leave it at work and bring your computer home virtually instead!

If you have a somewhat powerful computer at home you can turn it into a hypervisor and host a virtual clone of your work computer that can reside inside your own desktop computer. 

This guide will show you how, using Hyper-V.

**Disclaimer**

Please be aware that your computer's operating system may or may not work optimal in a virtualized environment. Try this on your own risk and treat it as experimental. The writer of this guide bears no responsibility. 

*It is strongly advised to do this with permission from your organization's IT or Cybersecurity department, as it may or may not involve additional security risks.*

**Requirements**

-   USB or External Hard drive with up to 50 GB free space.
    
-   Virtualization support and Hyper-V enabled on the designated host computer.
    
-   Preferably around 50GB free space on the designated host computer.
    

**Preparations**

In best case scenario you want to use a fresh installed work computer with as little software installed as possible. Only the necessary programs should be installed.

## Partitioning your disk

1.  Open “Disk Management” by right clicking the Start Menu and choosing it in the menu.
    

2.  Right-click the Windows volume and choose “Shrink Volume”
    

3.  You should shrink it as much as it is possible

4.  Click “Shrink”
    

5.  Create a new volume (D:-drive) from the unallocated space.
    

## Cloning your Windows installation and BOOT volume



1.  [Download Disk2vhd from Microsoft](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sysinternals/downloads/disk2vhd)
    

2.  Open Disk2vhd
    ![](data:image/png;base64,)

3.  Check the first `“\\?\\Volume{...}” BOOT volume` and the `“C:\” Windows` volume.  

    3.1 Check “Use volume Shadow Copy”  
    
    3.2 Check “Use VHDX”, vhdx is recommended for most situations but there can be performance benefits of using a VHD. 

    *[Read more about the differences between VHDX and VHD here.]({% post_url 2020-09-03-vhd-vs-vhdx-whats-the-difference %})*

    3.3 Select the VHD save path by clicking the three dots, point it to your secondary partition (D:\ by default).

4.  Click “Create”
    

**Copy the VHD file to your host computer**

1.  Plug in your USB or external drive to your work computer.
    

2.  Copy the VHD file from the location you saved it to previously.
    

3.  When the copy has finished, move the drive over to your host computer.
    

## **Setting up the Virtual Machine**
